Young people never fully recovered from the 2008 financial crisis. They now face the second major economic crisis of their young lives. And many borrowers, especially Black and Brown borrowers, are still drowning. We can do better this time ‚Äì we must do better. #CancelStudentDebt

Canceling student debt will help families spend money in their local communities and our economy. It will help them buy homes or start small businesses that create jobs. And it will take us a step closer to fixing a deeply broken higher ed system. #CancelStudentDebt

Executive action by the Biden-Harris administration to #CancelStudentDebt can boost Black and Latinx wealth, and help close the Black-white AND Latinx-white wealth gap by over 25%. That will help give Black and Brown families a far better shot at building some financial security.

Black and Brown students go to college because they believe it‚Äôs the surest path to build a future. They worked hard, did everything right, and often had no choice but to borrow loans. But student debt is a giant roadblock between them and building wealth. #CancelStudentDebt

1/3 of Latinx borrowers default on their student loans, and Black borrowers have about a 50-50 chance of defaulting on their loans. In fact, a decade after they start school, the typical Black borrower owes more on their loan than they originally borrowed. #CancelStudentDebt

For many systemic reasons, Black and Latinx households have a lot less wealth that white households. These students are more likely to borrow money to go to college, borrow more money while in college, and have a harder time paying when they leave college. #CancelStudentDebt

The point is, I‚Äôve looked at the data on this. And it‚Äôs wrong to think everyone with student debt is a college graduate. Millions of people struggle beneath a growing debt load without a degree to boost their earnings. #CancelStudentDebt

Up to 40% of people with student loan debt  ‚Äì and the majority of Black students ‚Äì don‚Äôt have a degree years after starting college. Maybe they couldn‚Äôt afford to finish, needed to work, didn‚Äôt have child care, life happened ‚Äì whatever. #CancelStudentDebt

Let‚Äôs just be clear: millionaires and billionaires don‚Äôt need to take out student loans, nor do their kids. Student loans are for people whose family couldn‚Äôt afford to write a check for college but who still tried to get an education anyway. #CancelStudentDebt

People still have questions about who benefits most if we #CancelStudentDebt. @SenSchumer and I set the record straight on who struggles with student loans and why it falls particularly hard on Black and Latinx students. Check out our new @Blavity op-ed. https://blavity.com/why-we-elizabeth-warren-and-chuck-schumer-believe-the-biden-harris-administration-should-cancel-up-to-50k-in-student-debt-on-day-one

RT @RepJerryNadler I'm so proud that the MORE Act passed the House by a bipartisan vote of 228 to 164. I introduced this bill to provide restorative justice, modernize America's cannabis laws, and deliver meaningful investments to America's communities & small businesses.
 
Now, let's make it law. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EoaaXaJXUAQGZ1g.jpg

According to the U.S. Sentencing Commission, nearly 84% of the more than 2,000 marijuana offenders who were federally sentenced in 2018 were people of color. 

Only 11% were white, although nearly 60% of the U.S. population is white.
In 2013, simple cannabis possession was the fourth most common cause of deportation for any offense and the most common cause of deportation for drug law violations.

Black men receive drug sentences that are 13.1 percent longer than sentences imposed for White men and Latino are nearly 6.5 times more likely to receive a federal sentence for cannabis possession than non-Hispanic Whites.

Thousands of men and women have suffered needlessly from the federal criminalization of marijuana, particularly in communities of color.

Here are the facts:

We must undo the damage that has been done to our communities since marijuana was arbitrarily placed on the list of controlled substances back in 1970. http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1334921946778247177/pu/img/b64AzN7aNjc6J3vI.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1334921946778247177/pu/vid/320x368/LqSb_211K9n-XDqW.mp4?tag=10

The continued enforcement of cannabis prohibition laws results in over 600,000 arrests annually, disproportionately impacting people of color who are almost four times more likely to be arrested for cannabis possession than their White counterparts, despite equal rates of use.
3. Expunge and seal Federal marijuana convictions and resentence offenders, as appropriate.
2. Sets up a taxation structure to collect a sales tax on marijuana, which would increase from five to eight percent over five years.
1. Removes marijuana, or cannabis, from the list‚Äîor the schedule‚Äîof Federally controlled substances.

I support the #MOREAct because it accomplishes three very important things: http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1334917037693530113/pu/img/DvKhZwbml5pHNu7E.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1334917037693530113/pu/vid/320x368/aD35gMJqeyhV0OIE.mp4?tag=10

There is no reason for cannabis to be classified as a federally scheduled substance under the Controlled Substances Act. The MORE Act deschedules cannabis, allowing states to establish their own marijuana regulations and providing medical marijuana access to veterans in need.

The MORE Act seeks to right the wrongs the War on Drugs perpetrated by expunging criminal convictions, reinvesting in communities of color, and promoting equitable participation in the legal marijuana industry.

America's marijuana laws disproportionately harm individuals and communities of color, leading to convictions that damage job prospects and the ability to vote. As the legal marijuana industry grows, Congress has a responsibility to ensure our policies are equitable & inclusive.
